thread.title: Police exhumed Indigenous baby's remains without speaking to elders: administrator
thread.title_full: Police exhumed Indigenous baby's remains without speaking to elders: administrator

author: Rebecca Opie
title: Police exhumed Indigenous baby's remains without speaking to elders: administrator
text:
By Rebecca Opie and Matt Coleman Posted February 06, 2017 14:54:16 Map: Marla 5724 
The removal of bones from an Aboriginal baby's grave on a sacred site should be investigated by the South Australian coroner, according to the administrator covering the area involved. 
The director of administration in the APY Lands, Rex Tjami, said that late in 2016, police exhumed the remains for forensic examination without speaking with the traditional owners. 
He said that happened after land management staff found the remains in a cave in the Sandy Bore Indigenous Protected Area in the Everard Ranges, in South Australia's far north. 
Mr Tjami said the removal had raised tension in the local communities amongst elders, who believe the remains had been there for about 60 years. 
"It wasn't respectful, that's the main one, it hurt us, without more conversation with elders," he said. 
Mr Tjami said his mother and uncle had told him that the child and their family had come from an area where there was nuclear testing. 
The child had become sick and died and was buried in the cave. 
Mr Tjami said that when he was taken to the cave after the child's remains were found, he noticed that the parents' cooking fire and grinding stones were still there â€” but the child's body had been taken. 
Police at Mimili had then told him that officers had taken the child's body for the coroner and that they did not appear to care what Indigenous people though about it. 
Mr Tjami said police later apologised to him. Government to pay for reburial 
"We are upset the child's grave was disturbed and the child's body taken away with nothing being said to APY anthropologists or traditional owners," he said. 
"We want protection for our heritage ... not people from Adelaide digging up old graves and taking away the bodies of our people without telling us. 
"I have asked my solicitor to write to the coroner requesting an inquest." 
South Australia's Aboriginal Affairs Minister, Kyam Maher, has also called on the coroner to review policies around the removal of bones from sacred burial sites for examination. 
"To avoid any future incident that may cause this type of distress," Mr Maher said. 
Mr Maher said the Government would cover the costs of reburying the remains. Coroner says he was told bones might not be ancient 
Coroner Mark Johns said that he found out about the remains in December 2016, when he was contacted by forensic pathologist Roger Byard, who was in the cave at that time. 
Mr Johns said Professor Byard reported the date of death may have been as recent as 10 years beforehand. 
The coroner said that because of that and having been told there were Indigenous community members at the scene, who had alerted police and who appeared to support forensic examination, he authorised the removal of the bones. 
Mr Johns said that it was not until 10 days later that he became aware of Mr Tjami's concerns and that he asked for a report from the police, which he said he still had not received. 
The coroner said each case of removal of bones from sacred sites must be considered on its merits and "it is not always possible to know the age of remains from a preliminary examination". 
"The circumstances of the finding of these remains certainly caused the police and Professor Byard to have reason to think the bones may not be Indigenous, nor that they were ancient," Mr Johns said. 
"After proper examination of the remains, Professor Byard is now of the opinion that the remains were Indigenous."
